summary: A December 30, 2020 letter from the U.S. Department of Justice's Office of International Affairs to an Assistant U.S. Attorney in New York, transmitting a formal Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty (MLAT) request from France. The request seeks U.S. assistance in the French criminal investigation into Jean-Luc Brunel, Jeffrey Epstein, and Ghislaine Maxwell, specifically for evidence and information held by U.S. authorities.

persons.name: Jean-Luc Brunel
persons.context: The primary subject of the French criminal investigation for which the MLAT request is made. Described as an accomplice of Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as the central figure whose actions, along with his accomplices, are under investigation by French authorities.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Named as an accomplice of Jeffrey Epstein. Evidence related to her was reportedly obtained during a search of Epstein's Paris residence.

connections.description: Brunel is explicitly described as an 'accomplice' of Jeffrey Epstein in the French investigation.
Maxwell is contextually linked as an accomplice, with evidence related to her found at Epstein's Paris residence.
Both are named as accomplices of Jeffrey Epstein and subjects of the same French investigation, with evidence linking them found at the same location.

events.title: Search of Epstein's Paris Residence
events.description: French authorities executed a search warrant at Jeffrey Epstein's residence in Paris, obtaining evidence and information relating to Jean-Luc Brunel and Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: U.S. DOJ Transmits French MLAT Request
events.description: The U.S. Department of Justice's Office of International Affairs formally transmits France's Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty request to the U.S. Attorney's Office in New York for execution.

locations: 2, avenue Gabriel, 75008 Paris (Embassy of the United States of America)
One St. Andrews Plaza, New York, New York 10007-1791 (U.S. Attorney's Office)
keyFacts: French authorities opened a criminal investigation into Jeffrey Epstein and his accomplices, notably Jean-Luc Brunel, with a focus on Brunel.
In September 2019, French authorities searched Epstein's Paris residence, obtaining evidence related to both Brunel and Ghislaine Maxwell.
The French investigation has identified multiple victims, but some potential charges are barred by France's statute of limitations.

France is formally requesting, via the U.S.-France Mutual Legal Assistance Treaty, a wide variety of information from U.S. authorities to aid their investigation into Brunel, Maxwell, and other specified individuals.
The U.S. DOJ instructs the receiving U.S. Attorney's Office to keep the matter confidential and file any necessary court applications under seal.
